Award.AwardTitle: 2020 Multifunctional Materials and Structures Gordon Research Conference; Ventura, California; 19-24 January 2020

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant will provide funds for the registration fees for 11 participants and partial domestic travel funds for 29 participants, including those from under-represented groups, of the 2020 Gordon Research Conference on Multifunctional Materials and Structures. This conference will encourage interactions between researchers from physics, mechanics, engineering science, chemistry, material science, biology, mathematics, and computational science and engineering working on the fundamental science and applications in multifunctional materials.

The participants will attend focused lectures that include a guided discussion period and will present posters. The technical sessions will cover the following topics: Materials of Architected Topology, Biological, Biomolecular and Bioinspired Materials for Sensing, Structural Remodeling and Morphogenesis, Brain-inspired Neuromorphic Networks, Structural Power, Avian Inspired Morphing Systems, Metastructures for Dynamic Response Tailoring, Reconfigurable Soft Robotics, and Multimaterial Additive Manufacturing. This project will facilitate the interaction of scholars from the variety of disciplines to address the fundamental scientific issues underpinning the advancement of hierarchical multifunctional material systems from the molecular scale to the macroscopic structural scale, and will provide an environment to promote networking and the formation of collaborative research endeavors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award supported the 2020 Multifunctional Materials and Structures Gordon Research Conference, “From Integrated Functions to Neuromorphic Networks and Soft Robotics” held in Ventura, California; 19-24 January 2020. The Gordon Research Conferences provides an international forum for the presentation and discussion of frontier research in the biological, chemical, and physical sciences, and their related technologies. For over 80 years, high-quality and cost-effective meetings organized by Gordon Research Conferences have been recognized as the world's premier scientific conferences, where leading investigators from around the globe discuss their latest work and future challenges in a uniquely informal, interactive format.

The conference was attended by 163 researchers who came together to discuss a wide range of scientific disciplines encompassing physics, mechanics, engineering science, chemistry, material science, biology, mathematics and computational science and engineering related to the emerging area of multifunctional materials and structures. Interdisciplinary dialogue is essential for the development of multifunctional material systems that have the ability to perform multiple functions through judicious combinations of structural properties and additional functional capabilities to deliver truly dramatic improvements in system-level efficiency. Inspired by biological systems there has been tremendous research progress in multifunctional sensing, actuation, computation, remote data transmission, morphing, threat neutralization, self-healing, regeneration, structure remodeling, structural power, and the nascent areas of neuromorphic networks, intelligent systems and soft robotic microsystems for self-learning and self-optimization.  Significant gaps remain in current understanding of how to seamlessly integrate novel functionalities into the load-carrying structures and to optimize the roles of interfaces and design/fabrication approaches. The fundamental scientific issues underpinning the advancement of hierarchical multifunctional material systems from the molecular scale to the macroscopic structural scale where discussed.

In addition to scientific discussions the programs “Power Hour” addressed issues of unconscious bias as other diversity, inclusion and equity issues. Attendees represented a diversity of race, gender and cultural from the international scientific community and included a mix of senior as well as junior level participants.

Funding was used to support travel and registration fees for graduate students, postdoctoral researchers and invited speakers.
